text: This is an article about the colour mauve. For information on the Flemish painter, see Anton Mauve. Mauve (pronounce to rhyme with "Jove" and "stove") is a pale purple colour. It is similar to lavender and lilac. The name comes from French form of malva meaning the "mallow" flower. Another name for this colour is mallow. The first recorded use of mallow as a colour name in English was in 1611. Maerz and Paul A Dictionary of Color New York:1930 McGraw-Hill Page 198; Color Sample of Mallow: Page 125 Plate 51 Color Sample I3 In 1856, an eighteen year old Chemist William Henry Perkin was trying to make artificial quinine. An unexpected residue caught his eye. It turned out to be the first aniline dye, mauveine. ==Meaning of mauve== * Mauve became very popular in the 1890s. This decade was sometimes referred to as the Mauve Decade, because William Henry Perkin's aniline dye allowed the widespread use of that colour in fashion. * The colour mauve became associated with homosexuality because well known figures in the art world during the 1890s--a decade that was called the Mauve Decade--were gay such as author Oscar Wilde and artist Aubrey Beardsley. ==Tones of mauve
